dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 2631 IH: Medical Information Nuanced Accountability Judgement Act of 2023
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Santos introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To prohibit the Federal Government from imposing any mandate requiring an individual to receive a vaccine that has not been authorized for marketing for at least 10 years, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Medical Information Nuanced Accountability Judgement Act of 2023 or the MINAJ Act of 2023.

section.header: Prohibition against vaccine mandates prior to marketing approval for at least 10 years

subsection.text: The Federal Government shall not establish, implement, or enforce any mandate requiring an individual to receive a vaccine that has not been authorized for marketing for at least 10 years.

paragraph.text: the mandate is intended to prevent or mitigate a disease with respect to which a public health emergency declaration is in effect; and
the Federal department or agency seeking to impose the mandate—

subparagraph.text: submits a report to the appropriate committees of Congress—

clause.text: giving notice of the intent to impose the mandate; and
including all data in the possession of the department or agency on the safety and efficacy of the vaccine involved; and

subparagraph.text: gives the appropriate committees of Congress a sufficient period to conduct extensive review of the matters in such report.

subsection.text: For purposes of subsection (b)(2)(B), a sufficient period shall be the lesser of—

paragraph.text: the period over which the appropriate committees of Congress each complete three hearings on the matters in the report submitted under subsection (b)(2)(A).
The term appropriate committees of Congress means—

subparagraph.text: the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives; and
the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions of the Senate.

paragraph.text: The term authorized for marketing means licensed, approved, or authorized under—

subparagraph.text: section 351 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 262); or
section 505 or 564 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 355, 360bbb–3).

paragraph.text: The term mandate includes any condition imposed on—

subparagraph.text: the receipt of a service or benefit.

paragraph.text: The term public health emergency declaration means a public health emergency declaration under section 319 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 247d).
